org.vertx.java.core.http

Class WebSocket

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.vertx.java.core.http.WebSocket
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ReadStream, WriteStream

    public class WebSocket
extends java.lang.Object
implements ReadStream, WriteStream

    Encapsulation of an HTML 5 Websocket

    Instances of this class are either created by an HttpServer instance when a websocket handshake is accepted on the server, or are create by an HttpClient instance when a client succeeds in a websocket handshake with a server. Once an instance has been obtained it can be used to send or receive buffers of data from the connection, a bit like a TCP socket.

    Instances of this class can only be used from the event loop thread which created it.

    Author:
    Tim Fox

    • Field Detail

      • binaryHandlerID

        public final long binaryHandlerID
        When a Websocket is created it automatically registers an event handler with the system, the ID of that handler is given by binaryHandlerID.

        Given this ID, a different event loop can send a binary frame to that event handler using Vertx.sendToHandler(long, T) and that buffer will be received by this instance in its own event loop and writing to the underlying connection. This allows you to write data to other websockets which are owned by different event loops.

      • textHandlerID

        public final long textHandlerID
        When a Websocket is created it automatically registers an event handler with the system, the ID of that handler is given by textHandlerID.

        Given this ID, a different event loop can send a text frame to that event handler using Vertx.sendToHandler(long, T) and that buffer will be received by this instance in its own event loop and writing to the underlying connection. This allows you to write data to other websockets which are owned by different event loops.

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Pause the websocket. Once the websocket has been paused, the system will stop reading any more chunks of data from the wire, thus pushing back to the server. Pause is often used in conjunction with a Pump to pump data between streams and implement flow control.
        Specified by:
        pause in interface ReadStream

      • resume

        public void resume()
        Resume a paused websocket. The websocket will resume receiving chunks of data from the wire.

        Resume is often used in conjunction with a Pump to pump data between streams and implement flow control.

        Specified by:
        resume in interface ReadStream

      • setWriteQueueMaxSize

        public void setWriteQueueMaxSize(int maxSize)
        Data is queued until it is actually sent. To set the point at which the queue is considered "full" call this method specifying the maxSize in bytes.

        This method is used by the Pump class to pump data between different streams and perform flow control.

        Specified by:
        setWriteQueueMaxSize in interface WriteStream

      • writeQueueFull

        public boolean writeQueueFull()
        If the amount of data that is currently queued is greater than the write queue max size see setWriteQueueMaxSize(int) then the write queue is considered full.

        Data can still be written to the websocket even if the write queue is deemed full, however it should be used as indicator to stop writing and push back on the source of the data, otherwise you risk running out of available RAM.

        This method is used by the Pump class to pump data between different streams and perform flow control.

        Specified by:
        writeQueueFull in interface WriteStream
        Returns:
        true if the write queue is full, false otherwise

      • writeBuffer

        public void writeBuffer(Buffer data)
        Write a Buffer to the websocket.
        Specified by:
        writeBuffer in interface WriteStream

      • drainHandler

        public void drainHandler(Handler<java.lang.Void> handler)
        This method sets a drain handler handler on the websocket. The drain handler will be called when write queue is no longer full and it is safe to write to it again.

        The drain handler is actually called when the write queue size reaches half the write queue max size to prevent thrashing. This method is used as part of a flow control strategy, e.g. it is used by the Pump class to pump data between different streams.

        Specified by:
        drainHandler in interface WriteStream
        Parameters:
        handler -

      • close

        public void close()
        Close the websocket
